abstract.p: The interactive visualization of equations in 3 0 PS potentially an important tool for both research and education. W e describe a method of visua1i:ing cquations in their explicit form using 3 0 fields. Equa2ion.s are written algebraically, interpreted b y an equation parser and then expressed as scalar fields. Fields are represented as isosurfaces making use of an algorithm similar to the method of marching cubes. The implementation allows the real time interaction of equalion parameters, isosurface rotations and colouring. A variety of applications from mathematics and physics a w given togeth.er with examples of the construction of data probes using equations.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: This paper reports work in progress by members of the IBM European Visualization Centre (EVISC).

The centre is an integral part of the IBM UK Scient.ific Cent,re (UKSC) in Winchester, England. The EVISC group provides advice and assistance to key IBM customers throughout Europe in the area of data visualization. The article covers the background and driving requirements of the work together with the methods used, application areas, and points for future attention.
